'''Johnnie Alexander Bassett''' (October 9, 1935 – August 4, 2012) was a Detroit-based American [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer, and songwriter. Working for decades primarily as a [[session musician]], by the 1990s Bassett had his own backing band and released seven albums in his lifetime. He cited [[Billy Butler (guitarist)|Billy Butler]], [[Tiny Grimes]], [[Albert King]], [[B.B. King]] and especially [[T-Bone Walker]] as major influences.<ref name="AMG" />

==Biography==
Born in [[Marianna, Florida]],<ref>{{cite news|author=Terence McArdle |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/music/johnnie-bassett-blues-singer-and-guitarist-dies-at-76/2012/08/09/704c89a4-e09c-11e1-8fc5-a7dcf1fc161d_story.html |title=Johnnie Bassett, blues singer and guitarist, dies at 76 |publisher=The Washington Post |date= August 9, 2012|accessdate=2012-08-19}}</ref> Bassett relocated with his family in 1944 to Detroit.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Richard Skelly |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/johnnie-bassett-mn0000241706/biography |title=Johnnie Bassett | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref> As a guitarist in his local group, [[Joe Weaver|Joe Weaver and the Bluenotes]], they won [[talent show|talent contest]]s, and locally backed [[Big Joe Turner]], and [[Ruth Brown]]. In 1958, Bassett enrolled into the [[United States Army]], but on his return to Detroit worked with the Bluenotes as [[session musician]]s for [[Fortune Records]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Bond">{{cite book
| first= Marilyn
| last= Bond
| year= 2002
| title= The Birth of the Detroit Sound: 1940–1964
| edition= 2nd
| publisher=Arcadia Publishing 
| location= Chicago
| isbn= 0-7385-2033-0
| page= 102}}</ref> During this time he provided accompaniment to [[Nolan Strong & The Diablos]] and [[Andre Williams]].<ref name="AMG"/>  He later backed [[The Miracles]] in a short tenure at [[Chess Records]], working on their debut single, "Got a Job" (1958).<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Mack"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vocalhalloffame.com/inductees/smokey_miracles.html |title=Smokey Robinson and The Miracles - Inductees - The Vocal Group Hall of Fame Foundation |publisher=Vocalhalloffame.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref><ref>[http://classic.motown.com/artist.aspx?ob=ros&src=lb&aid=38 ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref> In concerts while in Detroit, Bassett played on stage alongside [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Alberta Adams]], [[Lowell Fulson]] and [[Dinah Washington]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Basset spent most of the next decade doing gigs in [[Seattle]], also backing [[Tina Turner]] and [[Little Willie John]].<ref name="AMG"/> 

The Detroit Blues Society recognized Bassett's contribution to the blues with a lifetime achievement award in 1994.<ref name="Mack"/> He released the album ''I Gave My Life to the Blues'' on the Dutch label Black Magic in 1996, before recording and touring in North America and Europe with his own backing band, the Blues Insurgents.<ref name="AMG"/> Their 1998 album ''Cadillac Blues'' was nominated for five [[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Awards]].<ref name="Mack"/> His then [[record label]], Cannonball Records ceased to trade, but [[Mack Avenue Records]] signed him to a new [[recording contract]], after its owner saw Bassett and his band play in concert in Detroit's suburb of [[Grosse Pointe]].<ref name="Mack">{{cite web|url=http://www.mackavenue.com/artists/detail/johnnie_bassett/  |title=Johnnie Bassett – Artist Page |publisher=Mackavenue.com |accessdate=March 17, 2010}}</ref>

At the 2003 Great Lakes Folk Festival, Bassett performed as part of the Detroit Blues Revue with [[Alberta Adams]] and [[Joe Weaver]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://museum.msu.edu/glff2003/programs&activities/Music&Dance/artists/bassett.html |title=Artist Info |publisher=Museum.msu.edu |accessdate=March 17, 2010}}</ref> At the 2006 [[Detroit Music Awards]], Bassett won the 'Outstanding Blues/R&B Instrumentalist' title. In both 2010 and 2011, he was awarded the 'Outstanding Blues Artist/Group' title.

Bassett's album, ''The Gentleman is Back'' was released in June 2009. In 2010, it won a Detroit Music Award for 'Outstanding National Small/Independent Label Recording'.

Bassett and his band (Chris Codish – keyboards, Keith Kaminski – saxophone, and Skeeto Valdez – drums) played weekly at the Northern Lights Lounge in Detroit.

He died of cancer on August 4, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20120805/ENT04/208050325/Detroit-blues-man-Johnnie-Bassett-dies?odyssey=tab%7Ctopnews%7Ctext%7CFRONTPAGE|title= Detroit blues man Johnnie Bassett dies|publisher=Detroitnews.com|accessdate=2012-08-05}}</ref>

==Selected discography==
*''Live at the Montreux-Detroit Jazz Festival'' (1994)
*''I Gave My Life to the Blues'' (1997) – Black Magic
*''Bassett Hound'' (1997) – Fedora Records
*''Cadillac Blues'' (1998) – Cannonball Records
*''Party My Blues Away'' (1999) – Cannonball Records
*''The Gentleman is Back'' (2009) – [[Mack Avenue Records|Mack Avenue]]<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/johnnie-bassett-mn0000241706/discography |title=Johnnie Bassett | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>
*''I Can Make That Happen'' (2012) - Sly Dog Records<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.co.uk/I-Can-Make-That-Happen/dp/B007ZU6GSS |title=I Can Make That Happen: Amazon.co.uk: Music |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref>
